## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-02-27T14:30:22Z
## Message ID: 20160227-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2016-02-27T04:39Z.

Estimated speed: ~597 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 23 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -76/-20 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-02-27T04:39:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2016-03-01T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-02-27T04:39:00-CME-001):

http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160227_102800_2.0_anim.tim-den.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160227_102800_2.0_anim.tim-vel.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160227_102800_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160227_102800_2.0_anim.tim-den-Stereo_B.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160227_102800_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_A.gif
http://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/downloads/20160227_102800_2.0_anim.tim-vel-Stereo_B.gif


## Notes: 

[1] http://iswawiki.gsfc.nasa.gov/wiki/index.php/Glossary/Heliospheric_Earth_Equatorial_coordinates

SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 17, 2016 - February 23, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-02-24T22:30:13Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-02-17T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-02-23T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160224-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-02-17T21:00Z to 2016-02-18T00:00Z.  This elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-02-16 (see notifications 20160218-AL-001 and 20160218-AL-002).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-02-18T16:15Z and the levels remained elevated and crossed the threshold again on 2016-02-19T11:55Z and 2016-02-21T13:50Z. The significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20160218-AL-003, 20160218-AL-004, 20160221-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevation of energetic electron flux on the outer radiation belts described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2016-02-17T06:24Z     ~680            C               151/-30               21                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
2016-02-18T23:24Z     ~600            C               -37/-21               25                          STEREO A, SOHO                    
2016-02-21T12:09Z     ~653            C               120/-8                31                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-02-24T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-03-01T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There could be some activity originating from the far side of the Sun since there are several active regions that have the potential to produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections.  Moderate enhancement of geomagnetic activity is possible around 2016-02-25 due to the onset of a coronal hole high speed stream from the northern solar hemisphere.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-02-21T14:45:49Z
## Message ID: 20160221-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2016-02-21T13:50Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2016-02-16T01:55Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-02-21T13:50:00-RBE-001.

##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-02-18T01:28:17Z
## Message ID: 20160218-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-02-17T21:00Z to 2016-02-18T00:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2016-02-16T01:55Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-02-17T21:00:00-GST-001.

## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 4 M-class flares (see list below).     

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period 2016-02-16T18:00Z to 2016-02-16T21:00Z.  This elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2016-02-16 (see notification 20160216-AL-001).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Summary:

Intensifying space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2016-02-16T18:00Z to 2016-02-16T21:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at around 2016-02-16T01:55Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2016-02-16T18:00:00-GST-001.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Mars, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-02-12T02:27:23Z
## Message ID: 20160212-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

S-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2016-02-11T21:28Z.

Estimated speed: ~450 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 45 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): 3/14 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2016-02-11T21:28:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect Mars (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Mars at 2016-02-17T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2016-02-15T06:14Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 3-5 (below minor to minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME(s): 2016-02-11T21:28:00-CME-001):

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 03, 2016 - February 09, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-02-11T02:10:01Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-02-03T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-02-09T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160211-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2016-02-03T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2016-02-08T00:00Z-03:00Z. These slight elevations in geomagnetic activity were associated with the arrivals of two coronal hole high speed streams detected by ACE at L1 on 2016-02-03 and 2016-02-08.  The solar wind speed reached the peak speed of 517 km/s on 2016-02-05.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-02-10T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-02-16T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the solar disk with potential to produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections. We are also expecting slightly elevated geomagnetic activity around 2016-02-12 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 27, 2016 - February 02, 2016
##
## Message Issue Date: 2016-02-03T20:46:35Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2016-01-27T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2016-02-02T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20160203-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low level during this reporting period.  There were 4 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME that started on 2016-01-29T21:17Z may impact Mars around 2016-02-03T00:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20160130-AL-001).  Based on heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME that stared on 2016-02-01T20:54Z may impact NASA missions near Earth. Out of 48 ensemble members, 10 (20%) indicate impact at NASA missions near Earth about 2016-02-04T04:52Z and 2016-02-04T11:02Z (average arrival 2016-02-04T07:45Z). The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 97% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 2-5 range (below minor to moderate) (see notifications 20160202-AL-001 and 20160202-AL-002).

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2016-01-31T21:00Z-24:00Z.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2016-02-03T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2016-02-09T23:59Z

The solar and geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are a few active regions on the solar disk with potential to produce solar flares and coronal mass ejections. We are also experiencing some geomagnetic disturbance with Kp=5 for the synoptic period of 2016-02-03T03:00Z-06:00Z due to the arrival of the northern hemisphere coronal hole high speed stream.

S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
